Dialogue.Professor#1: $BGMEducation_BGM|Choosing Quality Education as our current topic now, are we?
Dialogue.Professor#2: Good good.As per my observation you do seem to carry with you a sort of arrogance in the way you speak,...
Dialogue.Professor#3: ...which means you most likely chose this because...
Dialogue.Samantha#1: $CEAttitude|$POS1|Of COURSE I would've received quality education, you have to be one of the stupidest things my head could ever make up.
Dialogue.Samantha#2: You claim to be all-knowing but you don't even know about how I graduated top of my class.
Dialogue.Professor#4: Now you are currently within the body of a person we have previously interviewed, Samantha Higgins.
Dialogue.Professor#5: She is, as you can most likely guess since you currently inherit all her personalities and memories,...
Dialogue.Professor#6: ...from a very comfortable background, top of her class in a prestigious high school and is very arrogant at times.
Dialogue.Professor#7: Now since you are doing this memoram in her perspective, you will have full access to her way of speaking.
Dialogue.Professor#8: However, I would also highly recommend seeking more...polite alternatives when you are allowed the choices in your dialogue.
Dialogue.Professor#9: Makes my life easier is all.Now, whenever you are ready.I will unpause and our conversation will start.
Dialogue.Player#3: Sure, let's get this over with I guess.
Dialogue.Professor#10: Yes, yes.If you would've let me finish my sentence I would've said what you just said.
Dialogue.Professor#11: BUT I can sense within you a tinge of uncertainty...
Dialogue.Samantha#3: $CEIdle|$POS1|Why am I even doing this? This is laughable considering I already AM thinking of studying in a university.
Dialogue.Professor#12: Are you now? Then you will have nothing to worry about then.This will just be right up your alley.
Dialogue.Professor#13: Now if you don't mind answering my question.
Dialogue.Samantha#4: As a matter of fact I DO mind answering your question actually.Maybe if you would just let me OUT of this stupid-
Dialogue.Professor#14: Great.Glad to hear such ardor from you.
Dialogue.Professor#15: Now from what I understand, you are already considering pursuing a higher education BUT now I understand your uncertainty.
Dialogue.Professor#16: You think it might not be worth it for you to study any further...
Dialogue.Professor#17: ...and that pursuing an education in a male-dominated field won't be worth it.
Dialogue.Samantha#5: I never said anything about that.Are you reading my mind?
Dialogue.Samantha#6: You are ridiculous.I am not the one that thinks studying any further could be a waste of time.
Dialogue.Samantha#7: My brother is the one that's thinking that.
Dialogue.Samantha#8: And of course he would think that too.
Dialogue.Samantha#9: He almost flunked out of year 9 and now he is talking about how he should just join TAFE to pursue a “trade” in plumbing.
Dialogue.Samantha#10: Talk about being the family failure.
Dialogue.Samantha#11: This is why I HAD to consider studying in STEM in the first place.Somebody's gotta make the family proud.
Dialogue.Professor#18: Well aren't you the best sister in the world huh.
Dialogue.Professor#19: Let's not persecute your brother right away.
Dialogue.Professor#20: From what I can observe, your brother isn't doing that badly in terms of his grades.
Dialogue.Professor#21: He can even choose to pursue a university degree if he puts his mind to it.
Dialogue.Professor#22: The problem stems from him thinking that it's pointless as if he gets his qualification from TAFE...
Dialogue.Professor#23: ...he can join the workforce and start earning money right away, rather than having to incur student debt.
Dialogue.Professor#24: Well, let's go ahead and find out whether his way of thinking is true or not.
Dialogue.Samantha#12: Sorry but why am I getting put through this trying to find out whether my BROTHER is making the right choice or not?
Dialogue.Professor#25: Because you are just a loving and concerned sister for your brother and you are just so concerned about his life choices.
Dialogue.Professor#26: Anyways, since you are such a know-it-all, why don't you sort through this table and tell me your observations huh?

Responses.Correct_Professor#1: Correct! The highest education level is most likely to earn a higher income.
Responses.Incorrect_Professor#1: Incorrect! The correct answer is the highest education level 'Postgraduates.

Dialogue.Samantha#1: And here I thought it was supposed to be hard, guess I could be getting out of this dumb dream soon after all.
Dialogue.Samantha#2: From my observation, this table shows that workers with the highest education level tend to earn a higher income.
Dialogue.Professor#1: Congratulations Samantha.You have answered the hardest question I can conjure up.
Dialogue.Professor#2: I am so happy to announce to you that I will be releasing you from your dream now.
Dialogue.Professor#4: I thought you were smarter than this Samantha.
Dialogue.Professor#5: Can't tell sarcasm apart from me being serious?
Dialogue.Professor#6: We still have to scrutinize other facets of our topic, otherwise I would be making it way too easy for you.
Dialogue.Samantha#4: I swear if I could call you names right now I would.
Dialogue.Samantha#5: Luckily for you, you somehow censored all those words from being able to be uttered in this space.
Dialogue.Professor#8: I appreciate the compliment.Have to make this space as comfortable and safe for everyone.
Dialogue.Professor#9: Well, have a look at this graph, give me your observations around how much a laborer/plumber would earn.

Questions.1: Labourers have the lowest median per/hour income.
Questions.2: Managers have the highest median per/hour income.
Questions.3: Professionals have the lowest median per/hour income.

Responses.Correct_Professor#1: Correct!, Labourers have the lowest median per/hour income
Responses.Incorrect_Professor#1: Incorrect!, Labourers have the lowest median per/hour income

Dialogue.Samantha#2: My brother would be earning way less than everyone else...
Dialogue.Professor#1: Not to anyone's surprise really, in general laborers earn less.
Dialogue.Professor#2: But here is the question, is that always the case and is it exactly true?
Dialogue.Samantha#3: How am I supposed to know the answer to that question?!
Dialogue.Samantha#4: I am not a statistics degree student now, am I?
Dialogue.Professor#3: Well isn't it just so convenient that the answers are now suddenly available to you like some thoughts in your head.
Dialogue.Samantha#5: I hate you, first you trap me in this hellscape.
Dialogue.Samantha#6: Now I find out you can just stuff whatever you want inside my head without asking me? When is this gonna end....

Responses.Correct_Professor#1: Correct!, It is false, there could always be someone that earns above the median and could possibly earn more than a professional or manager.
Responses.Incorrect_Professor#1: Incorrect!, It is false, there could always be someone that earns above the median and could possibly earn more than a professional or manager.

Dialogue.Samantha#2: It is entirely possible that there could always be someone that earns above the median...
Dialogue.Samantha#3: ...and could possibly earn more than a professional or manager.
Dialogue.Samantha#4: But a manager and professional could also possibly earn more than their median salary per hour.
Dialogue.Professor#2: Looks like you are finally getting your head around the idea of just answering my questions and stopping your whinging.
Dialogue.Samantha#6: Why are we looking at median salary, whatever that means, instead of the average salary per hour?
Dialogue.Professor#3: Oh my god wow.That is such a good question, Samantha.
Dialogue.Professor#4: Why don't you answer that question for yourself with these answers I am about to provide you.
Dialogue.Professor#5: The hint is that only one of them is the correct answer~~

Questions.3: The median is more accurate than the mean because it disregards the outliers

Responses.Correct_Professor#1: The median is more accurate than the mean because it disregards the outliers.
Responses.Correct_Professor#2: So the representation of what each profession will earn becomes less skewed.
Responses.Correct_Professor#3: The disadvantage of this is that it doesn't take all the data into account.
Responses.Incorrect_Professor#1: Incorrect!, It is false, there could always be someone that earns above the median and could possibly earn more than a professional or manager.

Dialogue.Samantha#1: Right, I am just gonna read off this answer you gave me, cause why not.
Dialogue.Samantha#2: “The median is more accurate than the mean because it disregards the outliers,...
Dialogue.Samantha#3: ...so the representation of what each profession will earn becomes less skewed.
Dialogue.Samantha#4: The disadvantage of this is that it doesn't take all the data into account.”
Dialogue.Professor#2: Now after seeing all of this, do you still want your brother to pursue the path that he will be heading towards before talking it out?
Dialogue.Samantha#5: Quite frankly, I could care less about what he wants to do with his future.
Dialogue.Samantha#6: But since I already have all this knowledge and information thanks to you injecting thoughts into my head.
Dialogue.Samantha#7: I might as well convey it to him when I get the chance.
Dialogue.Samantha#8: And I will be able to get that chance....if you just let me out now!
Dialogue.Professor#4: Now since we've addressed your concern with your brother,...
Dialogue.Professor#5: ...let's move on to your concern with pursuing a pathway of studying and working in a male-dominated field, especially in STEMs?
Dialogue.Samantha#9: Look, I already understand what I was signing up for when I thought about this pathway.
Dialogue.Samantha#10: I am in year 12 and am about to do my HSC, studying physics, chemistry, biology and engineering.
Dialogue.Samantha#11: Now I absolutely enjoy my classes and have no hesitation about the subjects I have chosen to study.
Dialogue.Professor#6: But you do have concerns about whether it is good for you to continue in this path when you go to university, don't you?
Dialogue.Professor#7: I do understand that the subjects you are doing are quite hard,...
Dialogue.Professor#8: ...and most of the time they are quite male-dominated which can sometimes make for a difficult environment to study in.
Dialogue.Samantha#12: I just....can you stop reading my mind? No seriously, this is getting weird.
Dialogue.Samantha#13: You are right, I came from an environment where I have been teased a lot.
Dialogue.Samantha#14: I am not exactly studying what a lot of girls in my grade are studying, especially by a lot of the boys in my class.
Dialogue.Professor#9: Well that's okay Samantha.Those are extremely valid feelings.
Dialogue.Professor#10: Now I can't promise to make you completely feel better, but maybe I can help you go through this.
Dialogue.Professor#11: Let me give some questions that will address these concerns of yours, and maybe they can help put your mind at ease.
Dialogue.Professor#12: Let's first look at this graph huh?
Dialogue.Samantha#16: Not to concern you, but you look real stupid right now.What graph are you talking abou-
Dialogue.Narrator#2: *Professor snaps his fingers and a graph pops into Samantha's mind*
Dialogue.Samantha#17: You wha- STOP! I can't.You keep putting things into my head, this is so disgusting.
Dialogue.Professor#13: Now now, chill out.It's just a graph, analyze the graph and tell me exactly what your observation is.

Questions.4: The graph shows that more females have obtained a higher education than males.

Responses.Correct_Professor#1: Correct!, The graph shows that more females have obtained a higher education than males.
Responses.Incorrect_Professor#1: Incorrect!, The graph shows that more females have obtained a higher education than males.

Dialogue.Samantha#1: Is it supposed to be reassuring to me that there are more females that have received a higher education than males?
Dialogue.Samantha#2: Look, as empowering as it is to see that statistics, it doesn't help ease my nerves around my peers, you know that right?
Dialogue.Professor#2: I know just letting you directly stare at statistics is not gonna give you too much comfort, but I will ask you a couple more questions.
Dialogue.Professor#3: Then you can decide for yourself how you can go about navigating your pathway towards higher education.
Dialogue.Professor#4: Now, can you answer me exactly how has education changed over the years?
Dialogue.Samantha#3: Okay, how am I supposed to answer that without...
Dialogue.Samantha#4: Actually nevermind, you are gonna do the thing that you do again, aren't you? Alright...hit me with it.

Responses.Correct_Professor#1: Correct!, Average years of education has increased by generation, ...
Responses.Correct_Professor#2: ...which means that future generations will be even more educated than the previous generation because more people are pursuing a bachelor's degree.

Dialogue.Samantha#1: Looking at these statistics, the future does look quite promising.
Dialogue.Samantha#2: More and more people in our generation are pursuing a bachelor's degree.
Dialogue.Samantha#3: Which means as generations go by, more and more people will be more educated.
Dialogue.Professor#1: That is CORRECT, Samantha.Look at you, what a smart cookie.
Dialogue.Samantha#4: And yet I still somehow don't see how that's relevant to me, Professor Know It All.
Dialogue.Professor#2: If you think about it Samantha, what conclusion can you draw after answering the previous two questions?
Dialogue.Samantha#5: I guess this means that over time, more people of different genders will become more educated, especially women.
Dialogue.Samantha#6: I guess it's a sign of progress for society, as it wasn't even that long ago when women were not even allowed to read books.
Dialogue.Samantha#7: Okay, I can see your point now.But here is my question though.
Dialogue.Samantha#8: I have noticed that at certain age groups, the amount of people choosing to study starts decreasing.
Dialogue.Samantha#9: Are there any particular reasons as to why that trend persists?
Dialogue.Professor#3: That is quite a good question.
Dialogue.Professor#4: Look at you asking the questions now, looks like you are starting to accept your situation and starting to want to learn now.
Dialogue.Samantha#11: One, I am trapped here regardless of my willingness in the situation, might as well make the most out of it.
Dialogue.Samantha#12: Two, this concerns how I perceive pursuing a path of tertiary education, therefore please show me the data without the extra fuss.

Responses.Correct_Professor#1: Correct!, Males recorded “no longer interested as to why they stopped 28.7% and females recorded that as their second highest reason.
Responses.Correct_Professor#2: Males second highest is “employment or financial reasons” at 26.1%, and females highest is “family, health or other personal reasons” at 29.6%.

Dialogue.Samantha#1: Interesting.So each demographic of people records different reasons for why they no longer study.
Dialogue.Samantha#2: So I am going to take a guess and say that the data would be different for my age group?
Dialogue.Professor#1: That is so correct! And that is because the mean years of education have increased over generations.
Dialogue.Professor#2: But here is another question for you, why do you think things are so different for you and your brother today?

Responses.Correct_Professor#1: Correct!, The male and females range from 15-64 which could include a large number of older generations that record less education.
Responses.Correct_Professor#2: Meaning maybe there was a higher pressure for men to focus on earning a living...,
Responses.Correct_Professor#3: ...whereas females were more focused on having a family.
Responses.Correct_Professor#4: Whereas today there is higher value on education and qualifications.

Dialogue.Samantha#1: I mean, from what I can tell, people from both of the binary gender demographic,...
Dialogue.Samantha#2: ...with their age ranging from 15-64, includes a huge number of older generations that records being less educated.
Dialogue.Samantha#3: From my understanding of the older generation, I am guessing there was just a higher pressure for men to focus on earning a living...
Dialogue.Samantha#4: ...and for women to focus on their own family back in the olden days.Whereas in our current generation, we place a higher value on education and qualifications.
Dialogue.Professor#1: That is absolutely wonderful Samantha.Perfect analysis on the subject matter.
Dialogue.Professor#2: Now to answer the most important question of it all, the one that you have been dying to know.
Dialogue.Professor#3: Are there many women who study STEM in university?

Responses.Correct_Professor#1: Correct!, Women are more prevalent in science than men, but in engineering, men have a significantly higher population.

Dialogue.Samantha#1: That's quite relieving to see that there are quite a number of women who choose to study STEM subjects.
Dialogue.Samantha#2: I guess that gives me some sort of comfort seeing so many women study in the science side of STEM subjects.
Dialogue.Samantha#3: Still it is quite a shame to see that there is significantly less percentage of women in engineering subjects though.
Dialogue.Professor#1: It definitely is quite a shame.
Dialogue.Professor#2: Although engineering is a difficult subject to grasp,...
Dialogue.Professor#3: ...I believe it is an advantage to see a diverse demographic within the Engineering field.
Dialogue.Professor#4: And as more and more people choose to pursue higher education, this data can change over time.
Dialogue.Professor#5: You can be part of that change too if you would like, it is ultimately up to you as to what you want to study though.
Dialogue.Samantha#4: Alright well, that was quite eye-opening and educational, I have a slight grasp as to my own future now.
Dialogue.Samantha#5: But I won't have a future to pursue, if you won't let me out.

Dialogue.Professor#1: $CEIdle|$POS0|$BGPovertyBackground|$BGMPoverty_BGM|Alright. Since you’ve chosen this level, you will experience this and answer my questions through the mindset of one of my favorite memoram, Elijah.
Dialogue.Professor#2: Now, if we may, we shall start right away.
Dialogue.Player#1: $CEIdle|$POS1|I can’t get used to this experience at all to be quite honest.
Dialogue.Professor#3: You will get used to it eventually.
Dialogue.Professor#4: For this topic, we will be using the memoram we obtained when Elijah signed up for one of our programs.
Dialogue.Professor#5: I have to say he was one of the more pleasant interviewees I have had the pleasure to do this program with, unlike yourself.
Dialogue.Professor#6: And therefore for my sake, I will be making this a third person memoram experience, just so you can’t ruin this for me.
Dialogue.Player#2: How fair. You absolute coward. If you are going to trap me, at least let me have some way to retaliate at you.
Dialogue.Professor#7: In your dreams. Now let’s begin, shall we?
Dialogue.Narrator#1: *Professor snaps their fingers and Elijah seems to come to life and starts animating*
Dialogue.Professor#8: Hello there. Elijah, correct? How are you doing? And what can I do for you today?
Dialogue.Elijah#1: $CEIdle|$POS1|Hello there sir! I am doing absolutely fantastic. It is such an honor to meet you.
Dialogue.Elijah#2: Since you asked, I will just go straight to the point then.
Dialogue.Elijah#3: I have been thinking about volunteering for support work to further develop my resume and grow my experience as a member of society,...
Dialogue.Elijah#4: …but I am currently struggling to search up relevant resources to develop my views on the reality of poverty within Australia.
Dialogue.Narrator#2: *winks at Player, and you roll your eyes*
Dialogue.Professor#11: Now since you got straight to the point that you need more information on the current situation of poverty within Australia.
Dialogue.Professor#12: Let’s take a step back and observe the meaning of poverty. Can you tell me what would be some indicators of poverty?

Responses.Correct_Elijah#1: From my observation, all of the answers seem to be indicators of poverty.
Responses.Correct_Elijah#2: Lacking money in a capitalist world is a very big indicator.
Responses.Correct_Elijah#3: Having limited to no access to food and clean water is also a big indicator.
Responses.Correct_Elijah#4: And a lack of shelter in our day and age can prove to be very problematic.
Responses.Correct_Professor#1: Absolutely correct, Elijah. Those are extremely good answers you’ve provided.
Responses.Correct_Professor#2: However, income is definitely the best numerical indicator for poverty as most definitions of poverty are mostly based on income.

Dialogue.Professor#1: Now comes another question, this is a graph that’s obtained from careful observations from my colleague.
Dialogue.Professor#2: From this graph, can you tell me the global percentage of people that are making less than $5.49 per day?

Responses.Correct_Elijah#1: That is absolutely terrible…… 37.1% of people globally are making less than $5 per day?!
Responses.Correct_Elijah#2: Living in Australia, I would’ve never heard of that, I can’t even imagine what that would feel like.
Responses.Correct_Professor#1: That’s okay Elijah, you don’t have to panic just yet.
Responses.Correct_Professor#2: I know it can feel very disheartening but that’s what I am here for, are you feeling okay?
Responses.Correct_Elijah#3: I feel okay to proceed, I just feel a bit sad to hear that people can still earn less than what they deserve.
Responses.Correct_Player#1: Well it is quite saddening to hear that.
Responses.Correct_Player#2: But what’s even more disheartening is that I am stuck here with an annoying know-it-all and a crybaby.
Responses.Correct_Narrator#1: *Professor stares at Player briefly and looks back at Elijah*
Responses.Correct_Professor#3: That’s okay, Elijah. It means you have basic sympathy.

Dialogue.Professor#1: Now I will say that sometimes the percentage does not represent the actual poverty rate.
Dialogue.Professor#2: Let’s try and understand that better shall we?
Dialogue.Professor#3: Now here is some dud data for you to practice on.
Dialogue.Professor#4: Can you please find out the mean and the median for the data that’s currently before you?

Responses.Correct_Elijah#1: The difference between the mean and the median is so huge. Wait, what’s causing this gap?
Responses.Correct_Professor#1: Incredible calculation and observational skill Elijah!
Responses.Correct_Professor#2: The reason why there is a big difference between the mean and median is because of the extreme variables within the dataset.
Responses.Correct_Professor#3: So this means depending on the subject, we need to actually consider which measurement is most useful to your current conclusion.

Dialogue.Elijah#1: Oh! That is so interesting. Can I-
Dialogue.Player#1: $CEIdle|$POS1|I am sorry, how is this question actually relevant to what Elijah is trying to understand?
Dialogue.Player#2: From what I understand about him, he is trying to obtain more understanding on the reality of poverty.
Dialogue.Player#3: So how is learning any of these yip-yaps about statistics supposed to help him?
Dialogue.Professor#1: Well, if you have simply allowed the memoram to play through,...
Dialogue.Professor#2: …you would’ve gotten to know how Elijah will gain an understanding of how poverty is in Australia.
Dialogue.Professor#3: But unfortunately, you just rudely interrupted our conversation and just paused the memoram.
Dialogue.Player#4: Well sorry for just wanting to gain some understanding and find relevance in these questions I guess.
Dialogue.Elijah#2: $CEIdle|$POS1|Can I then just choose the most appropriate measurement according to what’s required here?
Dialogue.Professor#5: Now think about this, if you are trying to carry out a study on the poverty rate in Australia with the data of everyone’s income, which measurement should we look at? The mean or the median?

Responses.Correct_Elijah#1: Oh! That makes so much more sense.
Responses.Correct_Elijah#2: Since our datasets will be based on income, it’s normal to have some extremely low or high values,...
Responses.Correct_Elijah#3: …and therefore it will be much more appropriate to use median income as a reference to poverty.

Dialogue.Player#1: $CEIdle|$POS1|Wow. We got a smart cookie over here.
Dialogue.Player#2: Now if he only knew that I am the one answering the questions and not him.
Dialogue.Player#3: How surprised do you reckon he would be.
Dialogue.Narrator#1: *Professor glares at Player momentarily before continuing*
Dialogue.Professor#1: That's right. We might think that poverty shouldn't be a serious problem here in Australia.
Dialogue.Professor#2: But if we take a look at the study by ACOSS(Australian Council of Social Service) and UNSW on the poverty issue in Australia 2021.
Dialogue.Professor#3: The study is based on the global standard poverty measurement which is 50% of the median income.
Dialogue.Professor#4: Now let’s think about it together. Which data should we be using as the measurement for poverty rate?

Responses.Correct_Elijah#1: $CEIdle|$POS1|I guess we would be looking at the 50% of median income cost?
Responses.Correct_Elijah#2: Simply because housing costs can be different for every individual.

Dialogue.Professor#1: According to their studies and surveys.
Dialogue.Professor#2: ACOSS and UNSW were able to estimate that 3,239,000 people in Australia are under the poverty line.
Dialogue.Professor#3: The population in Australia is around 23,810,000 in 2018.
Dialogue.Professor#4: Can you now work out the poverty rate from these numbers?

Responses.Correct_Elijah#1: The poverty rate is 13.6%. That’s still quite high.

Dialogue.Professor#1: The calculation of poverty rate is simply using the number of people below the poverty line divided by the total population.
Dialogue.Professor#2: Now go ahead and have a look at this plot of the trends in median household disposable incomes, before and after deducting housing costs.
Dialogue.Professor#3: Does this data suggest a positive relationship? What does this mean?

Responses.Correct_Elijah#2: The graph suggests a positive relationship, which means the poverty rate is increasing in Australia every year.
Responses.Correct_Professor#1: It is quite depressing just to look at the graph by itself, yes.
Responses.Correct_Professor#2: But this is exactly why volunteering work coming from young people like you can help make a difference.

Dialogue.Professor#1: Hopefully these statistics have helped you gain clarity in the current situation surrounding poverty in Australia.
Dialogue.Elijah#1: It has. Thank you so much for your help.
Dialogue.Elijah#2: When I first signed up for this program to try and gain more understanding on this subject matter…
Dialogue.Elijah#3: …I thought I would be scammed, I am very glad to have gotten to meet you now.
Dialogue.Narrator#1: *Your surrounding seems to freeze in place now and Elijah also seems to be frozen in place too*
Dialogue.Player#1: At least someone was glad to have met you I guess.
Dialogue.Professor#3: Well, that makes one of you guys.
Dialogue.Professor#4: Now I will also be asking you the same question.
Dialogue.Professor#5: Have you also obtained more understanding around poverty now that you’ve gone through Elijah’s memoram?
Dialogue.Player#2: If I say sure would you just let me out of here?
